definition: to feel the pulse/to take sb's pulse
handle
to hold/to contain/to grasp/to take hold of/handle/particle marking the following noun as a direct object/classifier for objects with handle/classifier for small objects: handful
arteries and veins/vein (on a leaf, insect wing etc)
see 脈脈|脉脉[mo4 mo4]

sentences.english: Let me feel her pulse, and take her temperature.
sentences.chinese: 我來給她把脈和量體溫。

sentences.english: The doctor felt the pulse carefully.
Could you feel my pulse and see if I'm all right?
sentences.chinese: 你能幫我把把脈，看看我是否正常嗎？

sentences.english: He feels my pulse and sees my tongue.
sentences.chinese: 他先給我把脈，又看我的舌頭。

sentences.english: They were headed home to hear a new president diagnose the state of America.
sentences.chinese: 他們趕着回家聽一位新總統爲美國聽診把脈。

sentences.english: Can you spare not me a less hours the despitenoon?
sentences.chinese: 能把把脈的具體時間安排得儘量早一些好嗎？

definition: (TCM) interrogation, one of the four methods of diagnosis 四診|四诊[si4 zhen3]
to put forward plans and ideas (also derogatory)/to give advice (idiom)
Chinese and Western medicine/a doctor trained in Chinese and Western medicine
to diagnose and treat
lit. to prescribe the right medicine for an illness (idiom); fig. to study a problem to find the right way to solve it/to take appropriate steps
cochlear implant
time bomb
warning sign/police call
unusual condition/something odd/strange shape
lit. to have one's hands bound and be unable to do anything about it (idiom); fig. helpless in the face of a crisis
to act with confusion/to be in a flurry/to be flustered
waiting to see a doctor/awaiting treatment
to bury oneself in work (idiom); to be engrossed in work/to make an all-out effort/up to the neck in work
diagnosis/to diagnose
dubious or hard-to-treat cases (medicine)/hard cases
to watch with folded arms (idiom); to look on without lifting a finger
